headline: English rendering of PM’s address during launch of development works, nationwide campaign for HPV vaccination from Ajmer
summaryText:
English rendering of PM’s address during launch of development works, nationwide campaign for HPV vaccination from Ajmer

On this sacred land of Tirthraj Pushkar and Mother Savitri, today I have had the opportunity to come among you, to receive your blessings. From this stage, I bow to the Tejaji Dham of Surasura and to the land of Prithviraj, Ajmer.

Brave Tejaji Maharaj ki Jai

Varun Avatar Lord Jhulelal Ji ki Jai

On the dais are the Hon’ble Governor of Rajasthan, Shri Haribhau Bagde Ji; the popular Chief Minister of the State, Shri Bhajanlal Sharma Ji; former Chief Minister, sister Vasundhara Ji; my colleague in the Union Council of Ministers, Shri Bhagirath Choudhary Ji; Deputy Chief Ministers Shri Premchand Bairwa Ji and Smt. Diya Kumari Ji; my colleagues in Parliament; the State President of the BJP, Shri Madan Rathore Ji; other esteemed Ministers; distinguished dignitaries; and my beloved brothers and sisters of Rajasthan. I am deeply grateful to the revered saints, who have graced this occasion in such large numbers to bless us with their presence.

Ajmer is the land of faith and valor. Here there are sacred pilgrimages, and also the footprints of revolutionaries. Only yesterday I returned to India after completing my visit to Israel. The people of Israel still proudly remember the valor of Rajasthan’s son, Major Dalpat Singh. I too had the privilege in Israel’s Parliament to pay homage to Major Dalpat Singh Ji’s bravery. I had the honor of recounting the glory of Rajasthan’s brave warriors who played a role in liberating the city of Haifa in Israel.

Just some time ago, the BJP’s double-engine government in Rajasthan completed two years. I am satisfied that today Rajasthan is advancing on a new path of development. The promises of progress with which the BJP government came to serve you are being fulfilled rapidly. And today is a day to accelerate this campaign of development. A short while ago, projects worth nearly 17 thousand crore rupees connected to Rajasthan’s development were inaugurated and dedicated. In every sector-roads, electricity, water, health, education-new strength is being added. All these projects will enhance the convenience of the people of Rajasthan and will also create employment opportunities for the youth of Rajasthan.

The BJP’s double-engine government is continuously empowering the youth. Two years ago, Rajasthan was in the news only for corruption in recruitments and paper leaks. Now, paper leaks have been curbed, strict action is being taken against the guilty. Today, from this very stage, appointment letters have been handed over to more than 21 thousand youth of Rajasthan. This is a huge transformation. For this change, for the new jobs, for all the works of development, I extend my heartfelt congratulations to all of you people of Rajasthan.

Today, from this land of brave women, I have had the opportunity to launch an important campaign for the daughters of the country. From here in Ajmer, the HPV vaccination campaign has been started. This campaign is a significant step in the direction of empowering the women power of the nation.

We all know that when a mother falls ill, the household feels shattered. But if the mother is healthy, the family can face any crisis with strength. With this sentiment, the BJP government has launched numerous schemes to empower women.

We have witnessed the time before 2014, when the absence of toilets caused immense suffering and humiliation for our sisters and daughters. Girls would drop out of school because there were no separate toilet facilities. Poor daughters could not afford sanitary pads. For those who were in power earlier, these were trivial matters, not even worth discussing. But for us, these were sensitive issues that harmed the health and dignity of our sisters and daughters. That is why we resolved them in mission mode.

During pregnancy, malnutrition posed a grave threat to mothers’ lives. We introduced schemes for safe motherhood, ensuring mothers received nutritious food, with ₹5,000 deposited directly into their accounts. Mothers used to cough in smoke but never complained. We said this cannot continue. That is why we launched the Ujjwala Gas Scheme. All this became possible because the BJP government works not with a sense of power, but with sensitivity.

A quarter of the 21st century has already passed. This is a crucial time for Rajasthan’s development. The BJP’s double-engine government is carrying forward both Rajasthan’s heritage and progress together. We all know that good roads, railways, and air connectivity don’t just make travel easier-they change the destiny of entire regions. When roads reach every village, farmers can sell their crops at fair prices. Traders can easily send their goods outside. And who doesn’t know the tourism strength of Ajmer-Pushkar? Improved connectivity has the greatest impact on tourism. When travel becomes easier, more people come to visit.

When tourists arrive, naturally hotels thrive, roadside eateries do well, kachoris and dal baati sell more, Rajasthan’s artisans find buyers for their crafts, taxis run, and guides get work. In other words, one tourist becomes the livelihood for many families. With this vision, our government is strongly focusing on modern connectivity in Rajasthan.

As connectivity expands in Rajasthan, opportunities for investment are also steadily increasing. Around the Delhi-Mumbai Industrial Corridor, a world-class infrastructure is being developed for industries. In other words, to make Rajasthan a land of opportunities, the double-engine government is working tirelessly in multiple ways.

Mothers of Rajasthan instill the values of patriotism in their children while raising them. This land of Rajasthan knows what respect for the nation means, and that is why today, on this soil of Rajasthan, I have come to share one more thought with you.

Recently, in Delhi, the world’s largest AI conference was held. Prime Ministers, Presidents, and Ministers from many countries attended the event. Leaders of the world’s biggest companies also gathered under one roof. Everyone openly praised India. I want to ask my brothers and sisters of Rajasthan-when so many people from around the world praise India, don’t you feel proud? Don’t you feel honored? Doesn’t your head rise high? Doesn’t your chest swell with pride?

You felt proud, but you also saw what the Congress, sunk in despair and exhaustion from continuous defeats, did. In front of guests from all over the world, Congress tried to defame the nation. They staged a whole drama to disgrace the country before foreign visitors.

Congress is losing across the nation, and in anger, they are taking revenge by tarnishing India’s image. Once Congress was the INC-the Indian National Congress. But today, it is no longer INC. Instead of INC, it has become MMC. MMC means Muslim League Maoist Congress.

My brave people of Rajasthan,

History bears witness that the Muslim League hated India, and that is why it partitioned the country. Today Congress is doing the same. Maoists too hate India’s prosperity, our Constitution, and our successful democracy. They attack from ambush. Congress also sneaks in anywhere to defame the nation. The country will never forgive such misdeeds of Congress.

Defaming the nation and weakening our armed forces has been Congress’s old habit. Remember, this is the same Congress that left our soldiers longing even for weapons and uniforms. This is the same Congress that deprived military families of One Rank One Pension for years. This is the same Congress under whose rule massive scams took place in defense deals with foreign countries.

In the past 11 years, India’s army has struck hard against terrorists and enemies on every front. Our army has been victorious in every mission, every battle. From surgical strikes to Operation Sindoor, they proved their valor. Yet Congress leaders chose to amplify the lies of our enemies. Whatever is good for the nation, whatever benefits the people, Congress opposes it all. That is why today the country is teaching Congress a lesson.

In Rajasthan, you have experienced Congress’s misrule closely. During its tenure here, Congress was entangled only in corruption and internal conflicts. Congress has always betrayed our farmers. Remember how Congress kept irrigation projects hanging for decades, causing immense loss to Rajasthan’s farmers. The ERCP project was trapped only in files and announcements by Congress governments. As soon as our government came, we worked to bring this scheme out of files and onto the ground.

The campaign to link rivers that our government has started will greatly benefit Rajasthan. Be it the revised Parvati-Kalisindh-Chambal link project or the Yamuna-Rajasthan link project, the double-engine government is committed to delivering the benefits of such irrigation projects to farmers. Even today, numerous water projects have begun for Jhalawar, Baran, Kota, and Bundi districts. Our effort is also to raise the groundwater level in Rajasthan.

The BJP government, understanding Rajasthan’s potential, is designing and implementing schemes. I am happy that Rajasthan has now become a land that earns prosperity from the power of the sun. We all know that Rajasthan has no shortage of sunlight. Now this sunlight is becoming a source of savings and income for ordinary households. And in this, the Pradhan Mantri Surya Ghar Free Electricity Scheme plays a major role. This scheme has the power to change Rajasthan’s destiny. Under this scheme, the BJP government provides ₹78,000 in assistance for installing solar panels on rooftops. The government transfers the money directly into your bank account. Look at all the budgets and schemes since independence-you will not find a scheme that benefits the middle class so much. Today, families are receiving ₹78,000 directly from the government to install solar panels. The middle class is benefiting the most. This creates a small power plant at home. During the day, electricity is generated from sunlight, which is used in the household, and the surplus electricity goes to the grid. The household that generates electricity also gains from it.

Today, more than 125,000 families in Rajasthan have joined this scheme. And because of this scheme, many households are seeing their electricity bills drop to nearly zero. That means expenses have reduced, and savings have increased.

We are continuously working on the mantra of “Developed Rajasthan for a Developed India.” The projects that have begun today will further strengthen the foundation of a developed Rajasthan. When Rajasthan develops, every family here will live a prosperous life. Once again, I extend my heartfelt congratulations to you all for these development projects. Say with me-

headline: “Convocation is not an end, but the beginning of the nation-building process”: Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan
summaryText:
Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers Welfare

“Convocation is not an end, but the beginning of the nation-building process”: Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan 365 students conferred degrees, 15 awarded gold medals at the Third Convocation of Rani Lakshmi Bai Central Agricultural University, Jhansi“Bundelkhand’s soil can become the centre of a pulses revolution”: Union Minister Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan“The goal of making India a ‘Food Basket’ will be achieved only when scientists carry knowledge from the laboratory to the field”: Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan

The Rani Lakshmi Bai Central Agricultural University, Jhansi, organised its Third Convocation Ceremony with historic dignity and enthusiasm. Union Minister for Agriculture and Farmers’ Welfare, and Rural Development, Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan, opened his address as the Chief Guest by raising the slogans “Bharat Mata Ki Jai” and “Jhansi Ki Rani Lakshmi Bai Ki Jai.” He personally conferred degrees on 365 students and honoured 15 meritorious students by awarding them gold medals.

Addressing the gathering, Shri Shivraj Chouhan said, “A convocation ceremony is not the end of life, but the beginning of a new chapter of nation-building.” Calling upon the students, he said that under the leadership of Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi, India is earning global respect, and it is now the responsibility of the youth to bring honour to the nation and their institution through their knowledge, skills and values.

Referring to Guru Dronacharya and the guru-shishya tradition, the Union Minister conveyed a message of integrity and dedication. Quoting inspiring thoughts, he said that students possess limitless potential; what is needed is the determination to set a goal and move forward with firm resolve.

Union Minister Shri Shivraj Chouhan highlighted the country’s food security and said that today India is not dependent on any country for food grains. He attributed this achievement to agricultural scientists and hardworking farmers. Emphasising the concept of a ‘Nutritious India’, he said that along with production, quality and nutrition are equally important.

He informed that the government is working towards making fertiliser subsidy transparent by transferring it directly into farmers’ accounts through Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT). So far, Farmer IDs have been created for 8.5 crore farmers, with a target of reaching 12 crore. Through the ‘Bharat Extension Platform’, farmers are being provided complete crop-related information on their mobile phones.

Shri Chouhan said that the soil of Bundelkhand has the potential to become the centre of a pulses revolution. He reiterated that the goal of making India a global ‘Food Basket’ will be achieved only when scientists ensure that knowledge travels from laboratories to farmers’ fields. Referring to his personal commitment, he said that he plants one sapling every day and appealed to everyone to plant at least one sapling on their birthday.

The Guest of Honour, Dr. M.L. Jat, Director General of the Indian Council of Agricultural Research and Secretary, DARE, described the university as an institution of national importance that is setting new benchmarks every day. He said that Jhansi is the land of revolution, and now it will become the birthplace of a new agricultural revolution in oilseeds and pulses.

Dr. Jat highlighted the role of intellectual property, innovation and scientific research in building a developed India. He said the university is not merely conferring degrees, but is building human resources that will determine the direction of the agricultural sector in the years to come.

He urged scientists to ensure that the benefits of research reach the last farmer in the queue. Research focused on climate change, natural resource management and value addition must be prioritised. He appealed to students to view agriculture as entrepreneurship and start-up opportunities and to play a leading role in building an ‘Atmanirbhar Bharat’ (Self-Reliant India).

Vice-Chancellor Dr. Ashok Kumar Singh welcomed the dignitaries and presented a detailed report on the university’s progress. He stated that the university, which began in 2014 with just five students, has today grown to 1,100 students and continues to progress steadily. He noted that the number of girl students is the highest. He added that, along with imparting education, the university has become a centre for technical advisory services, training and innovation for farmers.

In addition to the Jhansi campus, a College of Fisheries and a College of Veterinary and Animal Sciences have commenced in Datia, and studies at the College of Horticulture in Morena (Madhya Pradesh) will begin soon.

The Vice-Chancellor informed that the university has established several innovations, including a polyhouse, a high-tech nursery, an integrated farming system model, demonstration fields of durum wheat, mustard and gram, and a crop cafeteria.

He read out a pledge for daily plantation and presented it to the Union Agriculture Minister, reaffirming the university’s commitment to developing a ‘Green Campus’.

15 Gold Medals, 365 Degrees Conferred

At the ceremony, degrees were conferred upon a total of 365 students, including 235 undergraduates, 127 postgraduates and 3 Ph.D. scholars. Gold medals were awarded to 8 undergraduate, 7 postgraduate and 3 Ph.D. students for their outstanding academic achievements.

The programme began with the singing of Vande Mataram. The Chief Guest planted a sapling in the university campus and was accorded a Guard of Honour by NCC cadets. Several new buildings, including the Krishi Vigyan Mandap, were also inaugurated.

The Union Agriculture Minister interacted with farmers through a Kisan Chaupal organised in the university fields. He also visited the demonstration plots of mustard and gram cultivation and toured the integrated farming system model.

headline: APEDA Organises Sikkim Organic Conclave-cum-International Buyer Seller Meet in Gangtok
summaryText:
Ministry of Commerce & Industry

APEDA Organises Sikkim Organic Conclave-cum-International Buyer Seller Meet in Gangtok Knowledge Report on Supply Chain and Export Readiness of Sikkim’s Organic Produce Released at Conclave

The Agricultural and Processed Food Products Export Development Authority (APEDA), under the Ministry of Commerce & Industry, Government of India, in collaboration with the Government of Sikkim and in association with IFOAM-Asia, organised the Sikkim Organic Conclave-cum-International Buyer Seller Meet (IBSM) in Gangtok, Sikkim.

During the Conclave, a Knowledge Report titled “Study on Supply Chain & Export Readiness for Organic Farm Products in Sikkim” was released. Prepared by NICDC Logistics Data Services Ltd. (NLDSL), the report outlines a roadmap to strengthen Sikkim’s organic export ecosystem through improved infrastructure, streamlined processes, enhanced aggregation, transparent price discovery and strategic market positioning. It identifies measures to improve export competitiveness while ensuring sustainability, traceability and farmer-centric growth.

The event witnessed significant international participation, with around 40 buyers from 17 countries including South Korea, UAE, Mongolia, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Singapore, Norway, Kuwait and the United Kingdom, among other key markets. About 20 leading Indian exporters, including NCEL, Basillia Organics, Flex Foods and Nexton, participated in a structured Buyer–Seller Meet with approximately 100 Farmer Producer Organisations (FPOs/FPCs) from Sikkim. The interaction was coordinated by the Department of Agriculture & Horticulture, Government of Sikkim, and the Sikkim Organic Farming Development Agency (SOFDA).

The inaugural session was graced by Minister for Agriculture, Government of Sikkim, Shri Puran Kumar Gurung; Chairman, APEDA, Shri Abhishek Dev; Commissioner & Secretary, Department of Agriculture and Horticulture, Government of Sikkim, Shri Jigmee Dorjee Bhutia; Executive Director, IFOAM Organics Asia, Ms. Jennifer H. Chang; along with other senior dignitaries and officials from APEDA, the Government of Sikkim and stakeholders from the organic and export sector.

An exhibition featuring around 12 exhibitors showcased Sikkim’s certified organic products, including Large Cardamom, GI-tagged Dalle Khursani, Sikkim Mandarin, Buckwheat, Turmeric and Orchids. The exhibition highlighted the State’s diverse and export-ready organic produce and attracted interest from international buyers.

Sikkim became India’s first fully organic state in 2016, enabling its produce to gain recognition under APEDA’s export certification system. The State was conferred the Future Policy Gold Award by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in 2018 in recognition of its leadership in organic agriculture.

A technical session was also conducted to sensitise stakeholders on the 8th Edition of the National Programme for Organic Production (NPOP), covering updated regulations and labelling requirements. The session aimed to enhance awareness among exporters, FPOs and certification bodies regarding compliance standards, traceability norms and international equivalence requirements, thereby reinforcing India’s credibility in global organic trade.

The second phase of the event includes field visits by international buyers and exporters to high-potential organic production clusters in Sikkim. The visits are intended to provide first-hand exposure to certified organic farming practices, traceability systems, post-harvest handling and value addition processes. Interactions with farmers and FPOs are expected to strengthen farm-to-market linkages and enhance buyer confidence in Sikkim’s quality standards and export readiness.

Through initiatives such as the Organic Conclave-cum-IBSM, APEDA continues to promote organic exports, expand market access, build capacity among FPOs and exporters and position Sikkim as an important contributor to India’s growing organic export sector.

headline: NITI Aayog Convenes Frontier 50 Workshop: Advancing Intelligent Governance in Aspirational Blocks
summaryText:
NITI Aayog Convenes Frontier 50 Workshop: Advancing Intelligent Governance in Aspirational Blocks

NITI Aayog convened the Frontier 50 Workshop on 27th February 2026, under the Aspirational Districts and Blocks Programme (ADP/ABP), marking a strategic shift from digital governance to intelligent AI-enabled governance in public policy. The workshop was graced by Ms Nidhi Chhibber, CEO NITI Aayog, Prof Abhay Karandikar, Secretary Department of Science and Technology and Ms Debjani Ghosh, Distinguished Fellow and Chief Architect NITI Frontier Technology and Shri Rohit Kumar, Additional Secretary and Mission Director, Aspirational Districts and Blocks Programme, NITI Aayog, in the presence of senior Officers from the Central Government, State Governments and District Magistrates. Deliberations focused on operationalising Frontier Technologies across 50 Aspirational Blocks as real-world impact sandboxes. The ADP/ABP newsletter Aspirational Times was released during the Workshop.

The Inaugural Session underscored that India’s growth happens District by District. Technology was positioned as a strategic enabler of Viksit Bharat, moving governance from service digitisation toward adaptive intelligence and institutional reinvention. Speakers emphasised that Frontier Technology can unlock a national tech dividend, accelerate economic growth and social development and strengthen strategic autonomy. Core principles included focusing on real governance problems, enabling data-driven decision making, building institutional capacity, breaking silos and anchoring technology in leadership and trust.

Thematic Sessions on Frontier Technology

Eight Ministries had the platform to showcase the avenues of Digital Integration in decision-making at the District level. The National Quality Assurance Standards framework has certified public health facilities through the SaQsham platform across 29 States and UTs. Under POSHAN 2.0, the POSHAN Tracker monitors over 14 lakh Anganwadi Centres in near real time, transforming nutrition delivery into a measurable governance system. Under Jal Jeevan Mission, rural tap water coverage has expanded with geo-tagged assets and pipeline mapping on PM Gati Shakti, with emphasis on District Collectors, VWSC-led ownership and water quality testing. Digital livestock governance through Pashu Aadhar enables real-time vaccination tracking and AI-ready datasets for disease surveillance. The Digital Agriculture Mission is building interoperable digital public infrastructure through AgriStack and Bharat Vistaar integrating farmer registries, geo-referenced maps and multilingual advisories. In banking and financial services, AI supports credit scoring fraud detection AML and KYC automation and monitoring of financial inclusion indicators. Discussions also highlighted need assessments in borewell-dependent areas API integration improved POSHAN validation and AR-based training for frontline workers.

Group Discussion and Way Forward

Frontier Technology demonstrations included India AI sovereign stack applications presented by Shri Abhishek Singh MeitY, the NITI Frontier Tech Repository showcased by Ms Sachi Chopra, AI-enabled soil diagnostics, Sindhudurg as India’s first fully AI-enabled district under a state-owned SPV model and PadhaiWithAI in Tonk district improving Class 10 Mathematics outcomes. Under Frontier 50, AI Digital Intelligence and Telecom infrastructure are integrated through a phygital model with Samriddhi Kendras as assisted digital access points. This was also an opportunity for Districts to present their technology-driven interventions in addressing thematic challenges in their Districts and Blocks.

Towards the conclusion, NITI Aayog emphasised micro-localisation, interoperable district data stacks, measurable outcomes and accountable leadership.

Valedictory Ceremony Instrument Rating & Examiners' Course Aircrew Examining Board (AEB) of Indian Air Force marks a milestone with successful completion of 23rd Combined Instrument Rating Instructor and Examiner (CIRIE) course at Air Force Station Hindan.

Aircrew Examining Board (AEB), which is entrusted to uphold highest standards of flying in IAF, hosted valedictory function for its 23rd CIRIE Course on 27 Feb 2026 at AFS Hindan. The prestigious six-week program of this CIRIE course underscores IAF's unwavering commitment to excellence in aviation.

The ceremony was reviewed by Air Marshal Tejbir Singh, AVSM, VM, Director General (Inspection & Safety), whose vast operational experience added value to the occasion. Wg Cdr Deepak Awasthi, Wg Cdr Vishal Joshi & Wg Cdr Rohit Tiwari were felicitated by the reviewing officer for standing first in order of merit amongst aircrew from fighter, transport and helicopter fleets.

The course, spanning six intensive weeks, comprised four weeks of ground training and two weeks of flying training. This blended approach ensured officers master the complexities of evaluating instrument flying, critical for modern air operations in adverse weather and tactical scenarios.

A diverse cohort of 40 officers graduated from this elite program. Participants included 32 officers from IAF, two officers from IA, two officers from IN and four officers from friendly foreign countries, namely Kenya, Uganda and Madagascar. The exclusive course highlights increasing tri-service synergy and IAF's role as a global knowledge hub in the field of aviation.
